washing method: The green precipitate was washed with fresh NMP several times until the solvent appeared colorless.
The NMP was replaced by ethanol during multiple washing cycles
drying method: The supercritical CO2 was steadily released over 3 hours and the dry powder was transferred and stored in an argon filled glove box.
additional activation at 50 °C in a Schlenk-tube under dynamic vacuum of 10-3 mbar for 24 hours was performed
other: The ligand 9,9'-([1,1'-biphenyl]-4,4'-diyl)bis(9H-carbazole-3,6-dicarboxylic acid) H4BBCDC was synthesized following a procedure previously reported by our group.
To obtain crystallites small enough for the in situ PXRD investigations a slightly different synthetic protocol was used to synthesize DUT-49:

DUT-49 powder suspended in ethanol was placed in glass filter frits in a Jumbo Critical Point Dryer 13200J AB (SPI Supplies) which was subsequently filled with liquid CO2 (99.995% purity) at 15 °C and 50 bar.
To ensure a complete substitution of ethanol by CO2, the liquid in the autoclave was exchanged with fresh CO2 18 times over a period of 5 days using a valve at the bottom.
The temperature and pressure was then raised beyond the supercritical point of CO2 to 35 °C and 100 bar and kept until the temperature and pressure was constant.

To ensure a complete removal of ethanol (especially from the open metal sites of the Cu-paddle-wheels) additional activation at 50 °C in a Schlenk-tube under dynamic vacuum of 10-3 mbar for 24 hours was performed.
DUT-49 samples were transferred into the measuring cells in a glove-box under Ar-atmosphere (H2O, O2 < 0.1 ppm).
Before each adsorption experiment the sample was treated at 150 °C in vacuum for 3 h.
After the measurement the samples were transferred back into the glove-box.

removal of methane from CH4@DUT-49op can be achieved by increasing the temperature from 111 K to 298 K at constant methane pressure of 100 kPa (this should prevent a transformation back to DUT-49cp) and subsequent removal of the methane in dynamic vacuum for 12 h.
Corundum powder with a crystallite size of 5 µm was used as an external standard.
